trinity.title: The Mystery of the Holy Trinity
trinity.lead: Five Pillars of Mystery: The mystery of the Trinity

sections.title: Introduction to the Five Pillars
content: The Eritrean Orthodox Tewahdo Church has Five Pillars of Mysteries through which it teaches and demonstrates its basic religious belief. They are called Pillars of Mystery due to the fact that they support and strengthen the belief of the faithful in religious teachings just as a pillar supports a roof; These mysteries have Biblical foundation (1 Cor. 14:19).
Accordingly, the five pillars of mystery are expressed in the Orthodox Tewahdo Creed, which is the confession of our faith. The five mysteries of the church are as follows:

sections.title: Mystery of the Holy Trinity
content: In this section the mystery of Unity and Trinity of the Triune God is described. The Holy Trinity is three in name, in person, in deed and one in essence, in divinity, in existence, in will.

subsections.title: Three in Deed:
list: The Holy Spirit is the one who proceeds

subsections.title: Three in Person:
list: The Father has a perfect person
The Son has a perfect person
The Holy Spirit has a perfect person

content_after: The Father is the heart, the Son is the word and the Holy Spirit is the life (breath). The Father is the heart for Himself, and He is the heart for the Son and for the Holy Spirit. The Son is the word for Himself, and He is the word for the Father, and for the Holy Spirit. And finally, the Holy Spirit is the life (breath) for Himself, and He is the life (breath) for the Father and the Son.

sections.title: The Oneness of the Trinity
content: Even though we say the Trinity are three in name, in deed and in person; the Holy Trinity is also One as well. They are:
content_after: When an Orthodox Tewahdo believer says they believe in the Holy Trinity, it is not to say they believe in three Gods but one God. While the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit exist in their own perfect person, they are one in existence.

sections.title: Symbolic Metaphor: The Sun
content: There are many ways that the mystery of the Holy Trinity can be symbolized. For example, often times The Sun is used as metaphor to explain Qiddus Selassie or the Holy Trinity. The Sun can be described in three ways: its form, Light and warmth (heat).

Our fathers explain that its form is like the Father, the Light being the Son and the Warmth (heat) being the Holy Spirit. Just as one cannot separate the physical form of the Sun away from the light or warmth it gives, the same can be said of the Holy Trinity. The Holy Trinity describes the Father, the Son and the Spirit as being three while also being One. One cannot exist without the other two.

incarnation.title: The Mystery of the Incarnation
incarnation.lead: God becoming man for our salvation and the unification of Word and flesh

sections.title: Five Pillars of Mystery
content: The Eritrean Orthodox Tewaḥdo Church teaches its faith through the **Five Pillars of Mystery**. They are called "pillars" because, like pillars supporting a roof, these mysteries support the faith of believers. They are called "mysteries" because they are divine truths revealed by God and rooted in Scripture (1 Corinthians 14:19).

sections.title: The Mystery of the Incarnation
content: The Mystery of the Incarnation is the mystery of **God the Son**, one of the Trinity, descending from heaven and taking flesh and a rational soul from the Holy Virgin Mary. This is the mystery of **God becoming man so that man may become god by grace**. *"And the Word became flesh and dwelt among us" (John 1:14)*.

subsections.title: Why Did God Become Man?
content: Adam and Eve were created without sin and death. Through disobedience, humanity brought upon itself sin, suffering, and death. Yet God, seeing humanity's repentance, gave a covenant and promised redemption: *"For God has not appointed us to wrath, but to obtain salvation by our Lord Jesus Christ" (1 Thessalonians 5:9)*.

subsections.title: The Fulfillment of the Promise
content: When the appointed time came, God sent His only Begotten Son, born of the Holy Virgin Mary. In Christ, divinity and humanity were united perfectly, fulfilling the words of the prophets: *Isaiah 7:14, 9:6; Micah 5:2; Galatians 4:4*.

sections.title: The Logic and Philosophy of Tewaḥdo: Unification of Word and Flesh
content: In Ge'ez, **Tewaḥdo** (ጥዋሕዶ) means "to make one" or "to unify". It expresses the core Eritrean Orthodox teaching: the perfect, inseparable union of the **Divine Word (Logos)** and human flesh.

subsections.title: Logic: One Reality, Two Natures
content: Christ is one person with two natures:
content_after: They act together in one unified reality. Just as a human person is one being with body and soul, Christ is one person with divinity and humanity united.

subsections.title: Philosophy: Why "Without Separation" Matters
content: The union is:
list: **Without Confusion:** Divinity does not mix with humanity
**Without Change:** God remains God; humanity remains human
content_after: If divinity and humanity could separate, Christ's death and resurrection would not fully save humanity.

sections.title: Metaphors to Understand Tewaḥdo
list: **Human Person:** Body and soul are inseparable; so is Christ's humanity and divinity.
**Burning Coal:** Coal = humanity; Fire = divinity; burning coal = humanity filled with divinity.
**The Sun:** Sun = divinity; light = Word; warmth = humanity united to Word.
**Anointed King:** Man = humanity; anointing = divinity; anointed king = one unified reality.

subsections.title: Practical Meaning
content: **For Salvation:** Our humanity is united with divinity; Christ's resurrection and ascension become ours.
**For Worship:** We honor one Christ. Mary is Theotokos because she bore God in flesh.
**For Daily Life:** Christ understands our struggles and transforms them; our suffering can be holy in union with Him.

subsections.title: Deepest Truth
content: Wherever Jesus the man was, God was there. Whatever He suffered, God experienced. When He rose, death was conquered. In Communion, we receive God-in-flesh.
subsections.quote: "Like the soul giving life to the body is one person with it, so the Word of God giving existence to His humanity is one Christ with it. From conception, they were one."
